awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Efficacy of scaled up optimized urease producing microorganisms for manufacturing biocement binders towards a viable masonry construction material
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will test the efficacy of high-volume scaled microorganisms with the ability to induce cementation for masonry applications using methods proven at laboratory scale. Sporosarcina Pasteurii, a common non-pathogenic soil bacterium, has the ability to induce the creation of a biocement material, fusing loose grains of aggregate. Mineral growth fills gaps between the aggregate grains, biocementing the particles together in a structural bond, a process that takes a few days or less. The resulting material has a composition and demonstrates physical properties similar to natural sandstone. Traditional masonry manufacturing is reliant upon expensive fuel sources for hardening the final product, and these represent a large percentage of total manufacturing costs.  Biocementation at ambient conditions as a method for binding material into masonry units allows a cost advantage by eliminating the need for firing the final product.  The objectives of this effort include an extension of the baseline fermentation process for microorganism scale-up, testing of the efficacy of cell recovery, and efficiacy testing of the full-scale masonry product.  This research will also focus on testing the process efficacy with inexpensive industrial media in conjunction with high-volume fermentation and recovery practices. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the demonstration of the commercial viability of an optimized production process for masonry units (bricks) based on biocementation.   Over 80% of global construction uses masonry. Masonry manufacturing is a $24 billion business in the US. According to the Carbon War Room, 1.23 trillion fired bricks are manufactured globally each year, emitting over 800 million tons of carbon emissions.  Due to increased regulations introduced by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), several masonry companies have had to either shut down or invest significant sums in cleaner production methods due to these associated emissions. Government incentives for green construction, compounded with increasing sustainability concerns - for example, end users such as architects, are specifying the use of more sustainable materials - have created an opportunity for the adoption of "greener" cementitious materials. The societal impacts of this research will include a significant reduction of carbon emissions and the addition of manufacturing jobs in the US. Biocementation has also been investigated for use in soil stabilization and mine recovery. This project will enhance the technological understanding of this process, will help to establish commercial viability, and will generate additional practical data including durability and physical performance.

Portland Cement production is fossil-fuel intensive, and responsible for 3.4 billion tons of CO2, annually. Likewise, Fired clays are highly intense CO2 producers. Biocements made with microorganisms can be used as an economical and “green” alternative due to low energy requirements in manufacturing.

The mission of bioMASON is to produce a market and performance viable biocement. Biocements use significantly less energy than traditional cement production, due to low energy in manufacturing processes. The process works in ambient temperatures and does not require the use of fossil-fuels.

 

In this funded SBIR Phase 1 Grant, bioMASON tested the efficacy of scaled microorganisms with the ability to induce cementation using the Company’s existing methods at laboratory scale. The Company had already been able to produce full scale masonry material prototypes using small batch microorganism solutions with reagent grade materials, and used this SBIR as an opportunity to test efficacy with inexpensive industrial grade medias in conjunction with scale-up fermentation practices.

Objectives included:

            - Extending baseline fermentation processes for microorganism scale- up

            - Testing efficacy of a variety of packaging formats of cells

            - Biocement efficacy testing of the scaled organism with Industrial grade feed-stocks

 

The commercial value of this research is to optimize production for masonry units [bricks], as a minimum viable product with biocements. Masonry manufacturing is a large business in the US and on the global scale. According to the Carbon War Room, each year we produce over 1.23 Trillion fired bricks. Over 80% of global construction uses masonry

 

Government incentives for green materials, compounded with increased awareness of sustainable responsibility- end users such as architects, have specified more green materials- pushing companies to offer more variety in ‘green’ cement-based materials.

 

The societal impacts of this research are significant, and include:

                        -Reduction of CO2 emissions

                        -Increased manufacturing jobs in the US

                        -Reduction of waste [when feed-stock by-products are sourced]

 

This awarded funding enabled the enhancement of the technological understanding of optimization for commercial viability and constitute further tests for data including durability and physical performance.

 

BioMASON’s primary goal in the NSF SBIR Phase 1 was to optimize the large batch fermentation process, biomass recovery and efficacy testing of biologics for use in biocements. The research carried out in this process included optimization of the costs associated with the feedstocks for biomass production at BTEC (Biomanufacturing Training Education Center) and the viability of those fermentations on the biocement manufacturing process at bioMASON. Throughout the Phase I grant, bioMASON and BTEC worked to optimize the organism in scaled fermentation to test with current prototype production processes, in both small batch and masonry scales.
